item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://homepage-assignment-1.local.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Wordpress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
WordPress is a powerful and widely used content management system (CMS) that allows users to create and manage websites with ease. WordPress is highly customizable, offering thousands of themes for design and plugins to extend functionality, making it suitable for blogs, business websites, e-commerce stores, portfolios, and more. It is also SEO-friendly, scalable, and secure, with regular updates to enhance performance and safety.

Whether you are a beginner or an advanced developer, WordPress provides a flexible and user-friendly solution for building websites without needing to code from scratch.

Getting Started with LocalWP

To streamline my learning process, I used LocalWP, a powerful local development environment for WordPress. LocalWP makes it easy to set up a WordPress site on my computer without needing an online server. It offers features like one-click installations, database management, and SSL support, making development faster and more efficient.

Understanding WordPress Editors

WordPress offers different ways to create and manage content:

  • Block Editor (Gutenberg) – The default editor that provides a drag-and-drop experience with content blocks. It allows for visually structured content creation.
  • Classic Editor – A simple, traditional text-based editor resembling a Word-like interface, perfect for those who prefer a minimal editing experience.
  • Advanced Custom Fields (ACF) – A powerful plugin that lets developers create custom fields for posts, pages, and custom post types. This is particularly useful for dynamic and structured content that requires more flexibility than the default editor provides.

Understanding Posts and Menus

I learned how to create and organize posts using categories and tags, helping in better content organization. I also explored WordPress Menus, which allow for easy navigation customization, enabling users to structure their websites efficiently.

item.title: Posts
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Understanding WordPress Posts vs. Pages
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
WordPress offers two primary content types: posts and pages.

  • Posts are dynamic, appear in chronological order, and are best for blogs or news updates.
  • Pages are static and used for content like "About Us" or "Contact."
    When using a Query Loop block or a shortcode, you can dynamically fetch posts while keeping pages separate.
item.excerpt:encoded: Confused between WordPress posts and pages? Learn the key differences and when to use each.

item.title: How to Dynamically Display Posts in WordPress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dynamic post rendering in WordPress allows you to automatically display recent content without manually updating pages.
Methods to render posts dynamically:

  • Query Loop Block: The built-in way to fetch and display posts in Gutenberg.
  • Shortcodes: Use [latest_posts] or custom shortcodes to insert dynamic content.
  • Theme Templates: Modify PHP templates in your theme to show posts dynamically.
    🚀 Try using the Query Loop block and see how posts automatically update when new content is published!
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how to dynamically fetch and display WordPress posts using the Query Loop block and shortcodes.

item.title: Using Shortcodes to Display Posts in WordPress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Shortcodes in WordPress let you insert dynamic content anywhere on a page or post.
Example:


function retro_game_shortcode(){
    $query = new WP_Query(array('post_type' => 'retroGames', 'post_per_page' => 8, 'order' => 'asc'));
    while($query -> have_posts()) : $query -> the_post(); ?>
    <div class="retro-game-container col-sm-12 col-md-6 col-lg-3">
        <div>
            <a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>"><?php the_post_thumbnail(); ?></a>
        </div>
        <div>
            <h4><?php the_title(); ?></h4>
            <?php the_content(); ?>
            <p><a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>">Learn</a></p>
        </div>
    </div>

    <?php wp_reset_postdata(); ?>
    <?php
    endwhile;
    wp_reset_postdata();
}

Now, you can use [latest_posts] inside any page or widget to display recent posts!
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how to use shortcodes to display WordPress posts dynamically within pages and widgets.

item.title: Automating Content Updates with Dynamic Blocks in WordPress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tired of manually updating your WordPress content? Dynamic blocks can automate this process by fetching and displaying the latest data without editing the page every time.

What are dynamic blocks?

  • These are Gutenberg blocks that fetch and display live data.
  • Examples: Query Loop block, Latest Posts block, and dynamic text fields.

How to use them?

  1. Query Loop Block: Automatically lists recent posts from selected categories.
  2. Latest Posts Block: Instantly displays the most recent blog posts.
  3. Reusable Blocks: Update content in one place and see changes everywhere.

Bonus: If you want a custom dynamic block, try registering a block using register_block_type().

Dynamic content makes your site more engaging and automated! Try it out today!
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how dynamic blocks can automatically update your content in WordPress without manual intervention.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: What is LocalWP?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: LocalWP (commonly known as Local) is a development tool that allows you to create and manage WordPress websites on your local computer. It provides an easy way to set up a local WordPress environment without needing to configure a web server manually.

item.title: How to create a custom theme?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. Create a folder with the desired theme name in wp-content/themes/ directory.
  2. The theme folder must contains these files to work.
    • index.php - root file to render by the wordpress.
    • header.php - consists the header used for each page.
    • footer.php - consists the footer used for each page.
    • screenshot.png - serves as a thumbnail for your theme.
    • style.css - describes about your theme including theme name, author, version, etc.
  3. page-templates is a folder in which we can create reusable templates for pages of the website.

item.title: How to edit your page?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
• Default Content Editor - It is also known as the Block Editor and uses a block based approach providing drag and drop editing and built in design flexibility.
  • Classic Editor - It is like a basic text editor like Microsoft word. It provides a toolbar for formatting text, adding media and more.
  • Advanced Custom Fields (ACF) - It is a plugin that allows developers to add custom fields to WordPress posts, pages or custom post types. The fields can include text, images, etc. It requires php to display custom field data on the front end.
